head.title: Transformation of a Cluster-Based Metal–Organic Framework to a Rod Metal–Organic Framework | Chemistry of Materials

meta.content: Transformation of a Cluster-Based Metal–Organic Framework to a Rod Metal–Organic Framework

A highly stable and rigid rod metal–organic framework (MOF) is obtained by the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation of a Zr6 cluster-based MOF with highly interconnected but geometrically mismatched building blocks. The transformation results in a significant framework contraction, which comes from the formation of infinite chains of carboxylate- and aquo-linked Zr6 clusters as a one-dimensional rod secondary building unit. The permanently microporous rod MOF is stable in a variety of solvents, including H2O, and even under very harsh conditions, such as strongly acidic and basic aqueous solutions at 100 °C.

div.span: Supporting Info (4)

div.p:
A highly stable and rigid rod metal–organic framework (MOF) is obtained by the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation of a Zr
6
cluster-based MOF with highly interconnected but geometrically mismatched building blocks. The transformation results in a significant framework contraction, which comes from the formation of infinite chains of carboxylate- and aquo-linked Zr
6
clusters as a one-dimensional rod secondary building unit. The permanently microporous rod MOF is stable in a variety of solvents, including H
2
O, and even under very harsh conditions, such as strongly acidic and basic aqueous solutions at 100 °C.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as porous coordination networks, consist of metal ions or metal clusters as inorganic building blocks and organic ligands as organic building blocks interconnecting inorganic building blocks.
(1)
Among the various types of MOFs, Zr
6
cluster-based MOFs (Zr-MOFs) have attracted much attention because of their excellent stability in various solvents, including water.
(2,3)
The stability of Zr-MOFs stems from the combination of strong Zr–O coordination bonds and the framework rigidity of highly interconnected Zr
6
clusters in the network structure. Many robust and stable Zr-MOFs with different net topologies have been reported, where Zr
6
clusters, as an inorganic secondary building unit (SBU) ranging from 4-c to 12-c nodes, are connected by organic linkers ranging from 2-c to 4-c nodes.
(4)
However, several Zr-MOFs with (3,12)-c net topologies
(5−7)
are not as stable as other Zr-MOFs, despite being made of highly interconnected building blocks, and some being very flexible. The instability or flexibility of these Zr-MOFs is due to strained building blocks and/or strained linkages resulting from the geometric mismatch between inorganic and organic building blocks.
(8)

Some well-known MOFs, such as MIL-53,
(9)
MOF-74,
(10)
and UTSA-30,
(11)
are classified as rod MOFs,
(12)
which contain infinite chains of metal ions interconnected using oxo- and carboxylate-bridges as one-dimensional (1D) rod SBUs. The rigidity (or flexibility) of rod MOFs depends on the type and binding modes of the organic linker and the topologies of the rod network. Some rod MOFs, such as MOF-74 with organic linkers multiply ligated to the 1D SBU, are very rigid and stable, while other rod MOFs, such as MIL-53, are stable but flexible (or breathable) because of the rotation of the organic linker ligated to the 1D rod SBU, which acts as a hinge.
(9)
Rod MOFs are usually obtained by solvothermal reactions, as in other MOFs with finite metal ions or metal clusters as inorganic SBUs. A few Zr
6
cluster-based rod MOFs with ditopic organic linkers have been reported.
(13−15)
However, designing and synthesizing novel rod MOFs is considerably difficult because the organic linkers in rod MOFs usually participate in the generation of 1D rod SBUs in a very complicated polydentate binding mode, sometimes even with additional oxo- and/or hydroxo-linkages. In an effort to find novel Zr
6
cluster-based rod MOFs, we focused on Zr-MOFs with tritopic organic linkers that can tolerate framework strain coming from geometric mismatch between inorganic and organic building blocks and afford framework transformation.
(6,7)

Herein, we report the preparation of highly stable and rigid rod MOFs by the framework transformation of Zr-MOFs with highly interconnected but geometrically mismatched building blocks. The framework of the ZrBTE with (3,12)-c
llj
net topology transformed to that of the ZrBTE-rod with unprecedented rod net topology, based on the infinite chains of Zr
6
clusters as a 1D rod SBU, by a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) fashion (
Scheme 1
). The transformation resulted in a significant contraction of the framework volume; however, the framework still had permanent microporosity. The interconnection between the 1D rod SBUs using a rigid tritopic organic linker created a very stable and rigid framework. The ZrBTE-rod was stable for several days under very harsh conditions, such as in a variety of solvents, including H
2
O, as well as in 100 °C aqueous solutions with a pH range of 0–11.

Scheme 1. Transformation of ZrBTE with (3,12)-c
llj
Topology to ZrBTE-rod with an 8-Nodal (3,3,3,3,5,5,5,10)-c Rod Net Topology

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The solvothermal reaction of ZrCl
4
and 4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tris(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoic acid (H
3
BTE) in
N
,
N
-dimethylformamide (DMF) under acetic acid as a modulator produced a three-dimensional (3D) MOF [Zr
6
O
4
(OH)
4
(BTE)
4
(H
2
O)
4
] (ZrBTE), where Zr
6
clusters served as 12-c inorganic nodes and BTE ligands as 3-c organic nodes (
Figure 1
;
Table S1
). The framework of ZrBTE is the same as that of the reported TCM-16 with the (3,12)-c
llj
topology.
(7,16)
Typically, the Zr
6
cluster serving as a 12-c node in Zr
6
cluster-based MOFs has an octahedral local symmetry, with all the carboxylates bridging the bidentate binding mode. Conversely, the 12-c Zr
6
cluster in ZrBTE possessed a tetragonal local symmetry, and only eight out of 12 carboxylates bridge the bidentate binding mode. Further, the statistically disordered remaining four carboxylates were ligated to Zr ions in monodentate binding mode with four ligated water molecules (
Figure S1
). This tetragonal local symmetry of the 12-c Zr
6
cluster matches the site symmetry of the 12-c node in the network of the
llj
net topology.
(17)
However, the statistically disordered BTE ligand with one carboxylate in a monodentate binding mode was severely strained at the
C
2
v
symmetry site of the 3-c node in the network of the
llj
net topology because of the geometric mismatch between the 12-c Zr
6
cluster and BTE ligand. The in-plane and out-of-plane bending angles of the BTE significantly deviated from the ideal unstrained ligand geometry (∼12.0 and ∼6.0° deviations from unstrained in-plane and out-of-plane bending angles of 120 and 180°, respectively) (
Figure S2; Table S2
). The potential pore volume of the framework calculated using the Platon program
(18)
was 19,005 Å
3
, which corresponded to 80.2% of the total unit cell volume.

div.p:
Figure 1. Scheme of the ZrBTE synthesis and ZrBTE framework with (3,12)-c
llj
net topology viewed from two different directions.

div.h3: Framework Transformation and Structure of ZrBTE-rod
div.div:
The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals is in good agreement with the simulated pattern of the single-crystal structural model of ZrBTE (
Figure S3
). However, the PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals exposed to ambient conditions of ∼30% relative humidity (RH) for 1 h at 23 °C is similar but not identical to that of the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals. Therefore, to understand the factors affecting the transformation of ZrBTE into a new crystalline phase, the PXRD patterns of ZrBTE was investigated under the controlled conditions. At 25 °C, the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals show different transformation kinetics depending on the RH. It takes more than 8 days for ZrBTE crystals to transform to the new crystalline phase at 30% RH (
Figure S4
), but less than 30 min at 50% RH (
Figure S5
). On the other hand, the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals washed with volatile solvents such as methylene chloride or acetone are converted to the new crystalline phase within less than 2 min when exposed to 25 °C and 30% RH (
Figure S6
). Additionally, the phase transformed ZrBTE crystals show a change in the crystal morphology (
Figure 2
a). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of a phase transformed ZrBTE crystal seen from the approximate [0 1 0] direction is a characteristic image of rhombic frameworks (left of
Figure 2
b). The framework from the crystal structure of ZrBTE roughly matched the HRTEM image, where the red spheres overlaid on the HRTEM image represent the Zr
6
clusters in the crystal structure of ZrBTE. Conversely, the HRTEM image of phase transformed ZrBTE in the approximate [0 0 1] direction was completely different from the square framework expected from the crystal structure of ZrBTE. The HRTEM image indicated that it was a layered structure of Zr
6
clusters with an interlayer distance of ∼2.1 nm (right of
Figure 2
b), which cannot be explained using the crystal structure model of ZrBTE.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) ZrBTE crystals seen in the approximate [0 0 1] and [0 1 0] directions, respectively (top left and right) and phase transformed ZrBTE crystals seen in the approximate [0 0 1] and [0 1 0] directions of the ZrBTE crystal, respectively (bottom left and right). (b) HRTEM images of a phase transformed ZrBTE crystal in the approximate [0 1 0] and [0 0 1] directions, respectively. The red spheres representing the Zr
6
clusters in the crystal structure of ZrBTE considerably correspond with the TEM image of phase transformed ZrBTE viewed in the [0 1 0] direction.

div.div:
Despite the significant morphological changes, phase transformed ZrBTE crystals are still single crystals that are sufficient for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The structural analysis of the phase transformed ZrBTE (denoted as ZrBTE-rod) single crystals revealed significant changes in the framework structure (
Figure S7; Table S3
). The framework of the ZrBTE-rod seen from the [0 0 1] direction of the ZrBTE-rod crystals was very similar to that of ZrBTE seen from the [0 1 0] direction of the ZrBTE crystals (
Figure 3
a). However, the framework of the ZrBTE-rod seen from the [0 1 0] direction was completely different from that of ZrBTE seen in the [0 0 1] direction (
Figure 3
b). As shown in the TEM image in
Figure 2
b, the ZrBTE-rod possesses a layered framework with an interlayer distance of ∼2.1 nm. The framework based on a Zr
6
cluster as a 12-c SBU in ZrBTE was converted to a new framework based on an infinite 1D Zr
6
cluster-based chain as a 1D rod SBU (
Figure 3
c). The 12-c Zr
6
clusters in the square framework of ZrBTE contracted to a layered framework with three new linkages between the adjacent Zr
6
clusters by converting two out of four monodentate carboxylates into a
syn
-
anti
-type bridging bidentate mode and converting one out of four monodentate aquo ligands into a μ-aquo bridging mode while releasing the remaining three aquo ligands (
Figure S8
). These inter-cluster linkages afforded an infinite 1D rod SBU, resulting in Zr
6
cluster-derived 1D rod-based ZrBTE-rod, [Zr
6
O
4
(OH)
4
(μ-OH
2
)(BTE)
4
]. The simulated PXRD pattern of the single-crystal structural model of the ZrBTE-rod was also in good agreement with the PXRD pattern of the ZrBTE-rod (
Figure S3
). Zr
6
cluster-based rod MOFs are rare.
(13−15)
CAU-27
(13)
is one of the few examples of Zr
6
cluster-derived 1D rod-based MOFs, in which infinite chains of Zr
6
clusters are formed by four bridging bidentate carboxylate bonds in addition to the corner-sharing of Zr metal ions in Zr
6
clusters. CAU-22
(14)
and MIP-203
(15)
are other types of 1D rod-based MOFs based on Zr
6
clusters. However, unlike CAU-27, there is no corner-sharing of Zr metal ions in the infinite 1D chains of Zr
6
clusters. Additionally, the 1D rod SBUs in the ZrBTE-rod were based on interlinked Zr
6
clusters; however, the inter-cluster linkage was different from those of CAU-22 and MIP-203. While the Zr
6
clusters of the 1D rod SBU in CAU-22 were interlinked only by bis(μ-oxo) bonds and those in MIP-203 were interlinked only by bridging bidentate bis(formate) bonds, the Zr
6
clusters of the 1D rod SBUs in ZrBTE-rod were linked by both bridging carboxylate and μ-aquo bonds. The 1D SBUs in the ZrBTE-rod were further interconnected using tritopic BTE linkers. The framework of the ZrBTE-rod still possessed two different kinds of 1D solvent channels along the crystallographic
c
-axis in a 2:1 ratio, with diameters of ∼7.4 and ∼10 Å, respectively, despite the significant framework contraction. The potential pore volume of the framework calculated using the Platon program was 2695 Å
3
, which corresponded to 35.2% of the total unit cell volume.

div.p:
Figure 3. Framework structure of ZrBTE-rod seen from (a) the [0 0 1] direction and (b) the [0 1 0] direction. The yellow and green spheres represent approximate diameters of two different kinds of 1D solvent channels. (c) Transformation of ZrBTE to ZrBTE-rod by the formation of a 1D rod SBU with bis(carboxylate) and μ-aquo linkages between Zr
6
clusters.

div.div:
Surprisingly, the conversion of ZrBTE to ZrBTE-rod did not release the conformational strain of the BTE ligands in the framework of the ZrBTE-rod. The mean deviation of the in-plane bending angles of the two BTE ligands in the ZrBTE-rod (14.8°) was slightly larger than that observed in ZrBTE (12.0°), whereas the mean deviation of the out-of-plane bending angles of the two BTE ligands in the ZrBTE-rod (5.2°) was slightly smaller than that observed in ZrBTE (6.0°) (
Figure S2; Table S2
). The carboxylate residue of the benzoate group in the ZrBTE-rod was even more twisted from the benzoate molecular plane than that in ZrBTE (
Figure S9; Table S2
). The conversion of ZrBTE to ZrBTE-rod also resulted in a significant change in the knee-cap angle, defined as the dihedral angle between Zr–O–O–Zr and the benzoate planes. The knee-cap angle at the Zr-benzoate in a monodentate binding mode in the framework of ZrBTE (4.4°) significantly increased to 18.0 and 40.6° at the benzoates in
syn
-
anti
bridging bidentate binding mode and monodentate binding mode in the framework of ZrBTE-rod, respectively (
Figure S10; Table S2
). This kind of change in knee-cap angles, which is related to a kneecap-like rotation on the O–O axis of the carboxylate, as observed in DUT-98-cp,
(6)
was also observed during the breathing of other flexible MOFs, such as MIL-53 and MIL-88.
(9,19,20)
The net topology of the ZrBTE-rod, analyzed using the ToposPro program
(21)
after assigning the branching carboxylate carbon atoms of 1D rod SBUs as nodes and connecting these nodes to the nearest neighboring nodes as links, according to the suggestion of O’Keeffe et al.,
(10,12,22)
is an unprecedented 8-nodal (3,3,3,3,5,5,5,10)-c net (
Table S4
), where the net of the 1D rod SBU consists of infinitely connected edge-shared bicapped hexagonal prisms (
Figure 4
).

div.p: Figure 4. 3D framework of the ZrBTE-rod with edge-shared bicapped hexagonal prismatic 1D rod SBU linked using a 3-c BTE linker and the resulting rod network with (3,3,3,3,5,5,5,10)-c net topology. Black spheres representing branching carboxylate carbons are assigned as nodes in the 1D rod SBU.

div.div:
The framework conversion was partly due to enthalpic contributions arising from the formation of three additional linkages between the Zr
6
clusters in the 1D rod SBU in addition to the π–π stacking interactions between the benzoate residues of the BTE linkers and extensive van der Waals interactions between the BTE linkers in the closely packed framework of the ZrBTE-rod (
Figures S11 and S12
). The spontaneous framework conversion was also due to entropic contributions from the release of three ligated water molecules from the framework, in addition to the release of the solvent molecules encapsulated in the solvent pores. This conversion resulted in a 67.7% contraction of the framework volume, which is almost comparable to the highest value reported for MIL-88D, 70.0%,
(23)
and much larger than the values reported for DUT-50, 59.2%,
(24,25)
DUT-49, 53.1%,
(26)
and MIL-53(Cr), 29.7%.
(9)
Unlike other breathing MOFs, framework conversion is not reversible. Soaking the ZrBTE-rod in H
2
O does not lead to framework conversion back to ZrBTE. The ZrBTE-rod framework is very stable and rigid in various solvents, including water (
Figure S13
). The PXRD patterns of the ZrBTE-rod stored at 100 °C for 5 d in aqueous solutions with a pH range of 0–11 showed no deterioration in crystallinity (
Figure 5
). The framework stability resulted from the stability of the 1D rod SBU achieved by the additional linkages between the Zr
6
clusters and extensive π–π and van der Waals interactions between the organic linkers.

div.p: Figure 5. PXRD patterns of ZrBTE-rod in aqueous solutions with a pH range of 0–11. The pH of the aqueous solutions was adjusted using either HCl or NaOH.

div.div:
The N
2
adsorption isotherm of the activated ZrBTE-rod (ZrBTE-rod-a) at 77 K is a typical type I plot (
Figure S14a
), which confirms the microporosity of the framework. The specific pore volume estimated from the uptake amount (199 cm
3
/g at 0.99
P
/
P
0
) was 0.308 cm
3
/g, which was slightly higher than the calculated specific pore volume of the ZrBTE-rod from the single crystal structure, 0.298 cm
3
/g. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area
(27)
calculated using
P
/
P
0
between 0.00000743 and 0.0416 was 643 m
2
/g (
Figure S15
). Pore analysis, performed using non-localized density-functional theory,
(28)
indicated that the average pore dimension of the ZrBTE-rod-a was ∼0.8 nm, consisting of two slightly different dimensions of pores, as expected from the crystal structure of the ZrBTE-rod (
Figure S14b
). The meso- and macropores with a broad size distribution were generated during the conversion of ZrBTE to ZrBTE-rod.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. PXRD data were recorded using a Bruker D2 Phaser automated diffractometer at room temperature with a step size of 2θ = 0.02°.
1
H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded using an Agilent FT-NMR spectrophotometer (400 MHz). The gas sorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument with a standard volumetric technique up to the saturation pressure. N
2
sorption isotherms (99.999% purity) were monitored at 77 K.

HR-TEM was performed using a JEOL USA JEM-2100F (Cs corrector). For the HRTEM image of a ZrBTE-rod crystal shown in the approximate [0 1 0] direction of the ZrBTE crystal, the ZrBTE-rod crystals were grounded and scattered on the TEM grid. For the HRTEM image of a ZrBTE-rod crystal shown in the approximate [0 0 1] direction of the ZrBTE crystal, the specimen for HRTEM was prepared using a focused-ion beam (Helios Nanolab 450, FEI). The specimen sampling was performed at a tilt angle of 52° using a Ga
+
ion beam with an ion-voltage of 30.0 kV and a current of 2.5 nA. Fine milling was conducted using a Ga
+
ion beam with the same ion voltage of 30.0 kV but with a current of 0.23 nA to mill both sides of the specimen at tilt angles from 51.2 to 52.8°, and the specimen was loaded onto a TEM grid.

A mixture of 0.0372 g (0.160 mmol) of ZrCl
4
and 0.0408 g (0.0800 mmol) of H
3
BTE was dissolved in a solution of 10 mL of DMF and 3 mL of acetic acid in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. The solution was placed in an oven at 100 °C for five days to produce pale-yellow block-shaped crystals. The crystals were harvested and washed three times using 15 mL of fresh DMF.

ZrBTE-rod crystals were prepared by exposing the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals at 25 °C, 50% RH for 1 h or by washing the as-synthesized ZrBTE crystals three times using 15 mL methylene chloride (or acetone) and then exposing them at 25 °C and 30% RH. The ZrBTE-rod-a was prepared by heating the ZrBTE-rod crystals at 80 °C for 24 h under vacuum. After the N
2
sorption measurement, the
1
H NMR spectrum of the ZrBTE-rod-a was used to confirm the complete removal of all solvent molecules from the solvent pores.

div.div:
When the DMF molecules in the solvent pores are replaced by more volatile solvents such as water, methylene chloride, and acetone, the highly interconnected but geometrically mismatched Zr-MOF ZrBTE spontaneously transformed into a Zr
6
cluster-derived rod MOF ZrBTE-rod by the SCSC fashion. The transformation accompanying a significant framework volume contraction resulted from the formation of a stable 1D-rod SBU based on interlinked Zr
6
clusters with three new linkages between the adjacent Zr
6
clusters using two carboxylates in a bridging bidentate mode and an aquo ligand in a μ-aquo bridging mode. Afterward, the 1D-rod SBUs were further interlinked using the 3-c BTE ligand. The ZrBTE-rod is a rod network with an unprecedented 8-nodal net topology, where the 1D rod SBU is an infinitely connected edge-shared bicapped hexagonal prism based on the branching carboxylate carbon atoms as the nodes of the 1D rod SBU. Even after the significant framework contraction, the ZrBTE-rod still had two slightly different diameters of 1D solvent channels. The highly porous Zr
6
cluster-based 3D MOF with strained organic linkers can spontaneously convert to a more densely packed, highly robust rod MOF stabilized by additional π–π and van der Waals interactions between the organic linkers. This study shows that a combination of building blocks with high connectivities but mismatched geometries can afford an MOF with highly strained building blocks and/or linkages between building blocks. This MOF can be converted to a new stable rod MOF with additional linkages between the building blocks.

The chemistry and applications of metal-organic frameworks

Crystalline metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are formed by reticular synthesis, which creates strong bonds between inorganic and organic units. Careful selection of MOF constituents can yield crystals of ultrahigh porosity and high thermal and chemical stability. These characteristics allow the interior of MOFs to be chemically altered for use in gas separation, gas storage, and catalysis, among other applications. The precision commonly exercised in their chemical modification and the ability to expand their metrics without changing the underlying topology have not been achieved with other solids. MOFs whose chemical composition and shape of building units can be multiply varied within a particular structure already exist and may lead to materials that offer a synergistic combination of properties.

A new zirconium inorganic building brick forming metal organic frameworks with exceptional stability
Cavka Jasmina Hafizovic; Jakobsen Soren; Olsbye Unni; Guillou Nathalie; Lamberti Carlo; Bordiga Silvia; Lillerud Karl Petter
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2008
),

Porous crystals are strategic materials with industrial applications within petrochemistry, catalysis, gas storage, and selective separation. Their unique properties are based on the molecular-scale porous character. However, a principal limitation of zeolites and similar oxide-based materials is the relatively small size of the pores, typically in the range of medium-sized molecules, limiting their use in pharmaceutical and fine chemical applications. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) provided a breakthrough in this respect. New MOFs appear at a high and an increasing pace, but the appearances of new, stable inorganic building bricks are rare. Here we present a new zirconium-based inorganic building brick that allows the synthesis of very high surface area MOFs with unprecedented stability. The high stability is based on the combination of strong Zr-O bonds and the ability of the inner Zr6-cluster to rearrange reversibly upon removal or addition of mu3-OH groups, without any changes in the connecting carboxylates. The weak thermal, chemical, and mechanical stability of most MOFs is probably the most important property that limits their use in large scale industrial applications. The Zr-MOFs presented in this work have the toughness needed for industrial applications; decomposition temperature above 500 degrees C and resistance to most chemicals, and they remain crystalline even after exposure to 10 tons/cm2 of external pressure.

A review. Among the large family of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), Zr-based MOFs, which exhibit rich structure types, outstanding stability, intriguing properties and functions, are foreseen as one of the most promising MOF materials for practical applications. Although this specific type of MOF is still in its early stage of development, significant progress was made in recent years. Herein, advances in Zr-MOFs since 2008 are summarized and reviewed from three aspects: design and synthesis, structure, and applications. Four synthesis strategies implemented in building and/or modifying Zr-MOFs as well as their scale-up prepn. under green and industrially feasible conditions are illustrated 1st. Zr-MOFs with various structural types are then classified and discussed in terms of different Zr-based secondary building units and org. ligands. Finally, applications of Zr-MOFs in catalysis, mol. adsorption and sepn., drug delivery, and fluorescence sensing, and as porous carriers are highlighted. Such a review based on a specific type of MOF is expected to provide guidance for the in-depth study of MOFs towards practical applications.

In the past two decades, reticular chem. has developed into a powerful tool for the design and synthesis of porous, cryst. framework materials. The discovery of the first hexanuclear, zirconium cluster-based MOF (i.e. UiO-66; fcu net) led to a vast library of functional Zr-MOFs with various properties. The versatile connectivity of zirconium hexanuclear clusters and the adaptable tunability of org. ligands have resulted in the rational synthesis of a large set of Zr-MOFs based on edge-transitive nets; these nets commonly exists in cryst. network structures as suggested by reticular chem. In this review, we summarize recent advances in the synthesis of zirconium cluster-based MOFs in the light of reticular chem. design principles. Isoreticular tuning of MOF parent structures and post-synthetic modification of Zr-MOFs for targeted applications are also deliberated.

It is a general and common practice to carry out single-crystal x-ray diffraction expts. at cryogenic temps. to obtain high-resoln. data. This practice is not always applicable to metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), esp. when these structures are highly porous. Two new MOFs are reported, MOF-1004 and MOF-1005, for which the collection of the diffraction data at lower temp. (100 K) did not give data of sufficient quality to allow structure soln. Collection of data at higher temp. (290 K) gave at.-resoln. data for MOF-1004 and MOF-1005, allowing for structure soln. This inverse behavior, contrary to normal practice, is also true for some well-established MOFs (MOF-177 and UiO-67). Close examn. of the x-ray diffraction data obtained for all 4 of these MOFs at various temps. Disordered guest-framework interactions play a profound role in introducing disorder at low temp., and the diminishing strength of these interactions at high temps. reduces the disorder and gives high-resoln. diffraction data. The finding here probably is more widely applicable to other highly porous MOFs and crystals contg. highly disordered mols.

A flexible, yet very stable metal-org. framework (DUT-98, Zr6O4(OH)4(CPCDC)4(H2O)4, CPCDC = 9-(4-carboxyphenyl)-9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylate) was synthesized using a rational supermol. building block approach based on mol. modeling of metal-org. chains and subsequent virtual interlinking into a 3D MOF. Structural characterization via synchrotron single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) revealed the one-dimensional pore architecture of DUT-98, envisioned in silico. After supercrit. solvent extn., distinctive responses towards various gases stimulated reversible structural transformations, as detected using coupled synchrotron diffraction and physisorption techniques. DUT-98 shows a surprisingly low water uptake but a high selectivity for pore opening towards specific gases and vapors (N2, CO2, n-butane, alcs.) at characteristic pressure resulting in multiple steps in the adsorption isotherm and hysteretic behavior upon desorption.

A porous Zr-based MOF, [Zr6(BTEB)4(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(H2O)4], which contains partially hydrated, 12-connected {Zr6} nodes and extended carboxylate ligands (BTEB3-), was synthesized and physicochem. characterized. The resulting (12,3)-connected, 3D framework adopts an uncommon llj topol. with a large, solvent accessible void vol. of ca. 79% of the unit cell vol. The porous structure facilitates the uptake of N2 and activated samples give rise to BET surface areas of >1000 m2 g-1. Furthermore, the porosity and accessibility of Lewis acidic Zr(IV) sites promote the catalytic transformation of gaseous CO2 to cyclic carbonates via cycloaddn. reactions using epoxide reactants, whereby solvated MOFs exhibit higher catalytic performance than thermally treated samples.

A review. The past 20 years have witnessed tremendous advances in the field of porous materials, including the development of novel metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that show great potential for practical applications aimed at addressing global environmental and industrial challenges. A crit. tool enabling this progress has been reticular chem., through which researchers can design materials that exhibit highly regular (i.e. edge-transitive) topologies, based on the assembly of geometrically-matched building blocks into specific nets. However, innovation sometimes demands that researchers steer away from default topologies to instead pursue unusual geometries. In this perspective, we cover this aspect and introduce the concept of geometry mismatch, in which seemingly incompatible building blocks are combined to generate non-default structures. We describe diverse MOF assemblies built through geometry mismatch generated by use of ligand bend-angles, twisted functional groups, zigzag ligands and other elements, focusing on carboxylate-based MOFs combined with common inorg. clusters. We aim to provide a fresh perspective on rational design of MOFs and to help readers understand the countless options now available to achieve greater structural complexity in MOFs.

The 1st three-dimensional Cr(III) dicarboxylate, MIL-53as or CrIII(OH)·{O2C-C6H4-CO2}·{HO2C-C6H4-CO2H}0.75, was obtained under hydrothermal conditions (as: as-synthesized). The free acid can be removed by calcination giving the resulting solid, MIL-53ht or CrIII(OH)·{O2C-C6H4-CO2}. At room temp., MIL-53ht adsorbs atm. H2O immediately to give CrIII(OH)·{O2C-C6H4-CO2}·H2O or MIL-53lt (lt: low-temp. form, ht:high-temp. form). Structures, which were detd. by using x-ray powder diffraction data, are built up from chains of Cr(III) octahedra linked through terephthalate dianions. This creates a three-dimensional structure with an array of 1-dimensional large pore channels filled with free disordered terephthalic mols. (MIL-53as) or H2O mols. (MIL-53lt); when the free mols. are removed, this leads to a nanoporous solid (MIL-53ht) with a Langmuir surface area over 1500 m2/g. The transition between the hydrated form (MIL-53lt) and the anhyd. solid (MIL-53ht) is fully reversible and followed by a very high breathing effect (more than 5 Å), the pores being clipped in the presence of H2O mols. (MIL-53lt) and reopened when the channels are empty (MIL-53ht). The thermal behavior of the two solids was studied using TGA and x-ray thermodiffractometry. The sorption properties of MIL-53lt also were studied using several org. solvents. Finally, magnetism measurements performed on MIL-53as and MIL-53lt revealed that these two phases are antiferromagnetic with Neel temps. TN of 65 and 55 K, resp. Crystal data for MIL-53as is as follows: orthorhombic space group Pnam with a 17.340(1), b 12.178(1), c 6.822(1) Å, and Z = 4. Crystal data for MIL-53ht is as follows: orthorhombic space group Imcm with a 16.733(1), b 13.038(1), c 6.812(1) Å, and Z = 4. Crystal data for MIL-53lt is as follows: monoclinic space group C2/c with a 19.685(4), b 7.849(1), c 6.782(1) Å, β 104.90(1)°, and Z = 4.

The principal structure possibilities for packing infinite rod-shaped building blocks are described. Some basic nets derived from linking simple rods (helixes and ladders) are then enumerated. The authors demonstrate the usefulness of the concept of rod secondary building units in the design and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). Accordingly, the authors present the prepn., characterization, and crystal structures of 14 new MOFs (named MOF-69A-C and MOF-70-80) of 12 different structure types, belonging to rod packing motifs, and show how their structures are related to basic nets. The MOFs reported herein are of polytopic carboxylates and contain one of Zn, Pb, Co, Cd, Mn, or Tb. The inclusion properties of the most open members are presented as evidence that MOF structures with rod building blocks can indeed be designed to have permanent porosity and rigid architectures.

A review. Rod MOFs are metal-org. frameworks in which the metal-contg. secondary building units consist of infinite rods of linked metal-centered polyhedra. For such materials the authors identify the points of extension, often atoms, which define the interface between the org. and inorg. components of the structure. The pattern of points of extension defines a shape such as a helix, ladder, helical ribbon or cylinder tiling. The linkage of these shapes into a 3-dimensional framework in turn defines a net characteristic of the original structure. Some scores of rod MOF structures are illustrated and deconstructed into their underlying nets in this way. Crystallog. data for all nets in their max. symmetry embeddings are provided.

Two new Zr-based metal-org. frameworks [Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)6(BDC)3] (CAU-26) and [Zr5O4(OH)4(OAc)4(BDC)2] (CAU-27) are reported, which were synthesized from HOAc, a rarely used but green and sustainable solvent (BDC2-: 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). Structure detn. aided by automated electron diffraction tomog. revealed that CAU-26 [Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)6(BDC)3] is composed of layers of known {Zr6O8} clusters interconnected by terephthalate ions. In contrast CAU-27 [Zr5O4(OH)4(OAc)4(BDC)2] exhibits a three-dimensional structure with a so far unknown type of 1-dimensional inorg. building unit (IBU), which can be rationalized as condensed polyhedron-sharing chains of {Zr6O8} clusters. CAU-26 occurs as an intermediate of the CAU-27 synthesis and can be isolated easily, when reaction temp. and time are decreased. The authors were also able to synthesize two isoreticular derivs. of CAU-27 with extended linker mols. by implementing 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC) and 5,5'-dicarboxy-2,2'-bipyridine (H2BIPY). All materials show high thermal and chem. stability as well as permanent microporosity. The excellent stability of CAU-27-BIPY was exploited to synthesize an Ir-supported heterogeneous MOF-based catalyst for the direct C-H borylation of arenes.

Engineering the structural flexibility of metal-org. framework (MOF) materials for sepn.-related applications remains a great challenge. We present here a strategy of mixing rigid and soft linkers in a MOF structure to achieve tunable structural flexibility, as exemplified in a series of stable isostructural Zr-MOFs built with natural C4 linkers (fumaric acid, succinic acid, and malic acid). As shown by the differences in linker bond stretching and bending freedom, these MOFs display distinct responsive dynamics to external stimuli, namely, changes in temp. or guest mol. type. Comprehensive in situ characterizations reveal a clear correlation between linker character and MOF dynamic behavior, which leads to the discovery of a multivariate flexible MOF. It shows an optimal combination of both good working capacity and significantly enhanced selectivity for CO2/N2 sepn. In principle, it provides a new avenue for potentially improving the ability of microporous MOFs to sep. other gaseous and liq. mixts.

The Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database of, and symbols for, crystal nets
O'Keeffe, Michael; Peskov, Maxim A.; Ramsden, Stuart J.; Yaghi, Omar M.

During the past decade, interest has grown tremendously in the design and synthesis of cryst. materials constructed from mol. clusters linked by extended groups of atoms. Most notable are metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), in which polyat. inorg. metal-contg. clusters are joined by polytopic linkers. (Although these materials are sometimes referred to as coordination polymers, we prefer to differentiate them, because MOFs are based on strong linkages that yield robust frameworks.) The realization that MOFs could be designed and synthesized in a rational way from mol. building blocks led to the emergence of a discipline that we call reticular chem.MOFs can be represented as a special kind of graph called a periodic net. Such descriptions date back to the earliest crystallog. studies but have become much more common recently because thousands of new structures and hundreds of underlying nets have been reported. In the simplest cases (e.g., the structure of diamond), the atoms in the crystal become the vertices of the net, and bonds are the links (edges) that connect them. In the case of MOFs, polyat. groups act as the vertices and edges of the net.Because of the explosive growth in this area, a need has arisen for a universal system of nomenclature, classification, identification, and retrieval of these topol. structures. We have developed a system of symbols for the identification of three periodic nets of interest, and this system is now in wide use. In this Account, we explain the underlying methodol. of assigning symbols and describe the Reticular Chem. Structure Resource (RCSR), in which about 1600 such nets are collected and illustrated in a database that can be searched by symbol, name, keywords, and attributes. The resource also contains searchable data for polyhedra and layers.The database entries come from systematic enumerations or from known chem. compds. or both. In the latter case, refs. to occurrences are provided. We describe some crystallog., topol., and other attributes of nets and explain how they are reported in the database. We also describe how the database can be used as a tool for the design and structural anal. of new materials. Assocd. with each net is a natural tiling, which is a natural partition of space into space-filling tiles. The database allows export of data that can be used to analyze and illustrate such tilings.

PLATON SQUEEZE: a tool for the calculation of the disordered solvent contribution to the calculated structure factors
Spek, Anthony L.
Acta Crystallographica, Section C: Structural Chemistry
(
2015
),
71
(
1

9-18

ACSCGG
; ISSN:
2053-2296
.
(
International Union of Crystallography
)
The completion of a crystal structure detn. is often hampered by the presence of embedded solvent mols. or ions that are seriously disordered. Their contribution to the calcd. structure factors in the least-squares refinement of a crystal structure has to be included in some way. Traditionally, an atomistic solvent disorder model is attempted. Such an approach is generally to be preferred, but it does not always lead to a satisfactory result and may even be impossible in cases where channels in the structure are filled with continuous electron d. This paper documents the SQUEEZE method as an alternative means of addressing the solvent disorder issue. It conveniently interfaces with the 2014 version of the least-squares refinement program SHELXL [Sheldrick (2015). Acta Cryst. C71. In the press] and other refinement programs that accept externally provided fixed contributions to the calcd. structure factors. The PLATON SQUEEZE tool calcs. the solvent contribution to the structure factors by back-Fourier transformation of the electron d. found in the solvent-accessible region of a phase-optimized difference electron-d. map. The actual least-squares structure refinement is delegated to, for example, SHELXL. The current versions of PLATON SQUEEZE and SHELXL now address several of the unnecessary complications with the earlier implementation of the SQUEEZE procedure that were a necessity because least-squares refinement with the now superseded SHELXL97 program did not allow for the input of fixed externally provided contributions to the structure-factor calcn. It is no longer necessary to subtract the solvent contribution temporarily from the obsd. intensities to be able to use SHELXL for the least-squares refinement, since that program now accepts the solvent contribution from an external file ( file) if the ABIN instruction is used. In addn., many twinned structures contg. disordered solvents are now also treatable by SQUEEZE. The details of a SQUEEZE calcn. are now automatically included in the CIF archive file, along with the unmerged reflection data. The current implementation of the SQUEEZE procedure is described, and discussed and illustrated with three examples. Two of them are based on the reflection data of published structures and one on synthetic reflection data generated for a published structure.

Towards general network architecture design criteria for negative gas adsorption transitions in ultraporous frameworks
Krause Simon; Evans Jack D; Bon Volodymyr; Senkovska Irena; Kolbe Felicitas; Ehrling Sebastian; Troschke Erik; Getzschmann Jurgen; Brunner Eike; Kaskel Stefan; Evans Jack D; Coudert Francois-Xavier; Iacomi Paul; Llewellyn Philip L; Tobbens Daniel M; Franz Alexandra; Wallacher Dirk; Yot Pascal G; Maurin Guillaume
Nature communications
(
2019
),
10
(
1
),
3632
ISSN:
.
Switchable metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been proposed for various energy-related storage and separation applications, but the mechanistic understanding of adsorption-induced switching transitions is still at an early stage. Here we report critical design criteria for negative gas adsorption (NGA), a counterintuitive feature of pressure amplifying materials, hitherto uniquely observed in a highly porous framework compound (DUT-49). These criteria are derived by analysing the physical effects of micromechanics, pore size, interpenetration, adsorption enthalpies, and the pore filling mechanism using advanced in situ X-ray and neutron diffraction, NMR spectroscopy, and calorimetric techniques parallelised to adsorption for a series of six isoreticular networks. Aided by computational modelling, we identify DUT-50 as a new pressure amplifying material featuring distinct NGA transitions upon methane and argon adsorption. In situ neutron diffraction analysis of the methane (CD4) adsorption sites at 111 K supported by grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations reveals a sudden population of the largest mesopore to be the critical filling step initiating structural contraction and NGA. In contrast, interpenetration leads to framework stiffening and specific pore volume reduction, both factors effectively suppressing NGA transitions.

Herein we demonstrate mesoporous frameworks interacting with carbon dioxide leading to stimulated structural contractions and massive out-of-equil. pressure amplification well beyond ambient pressure. Carbon dioxide, a non-toxic and non-flammable working medium, is promising for the development of pressure-amplifying frameworks for pneumatic technologies and safety systems. The strong interaction of the fluid with the framework even contracts DUT-46, a framework hitherto considered as non-flexible. Synchrotron-based in situ PXRD/adsorption expts. reveal the characteristic contraction pressure for DUT-49 pressure amplification in the range of 350-680 kPa. The stimulated framework contraction expels 1.1 to 2.4 mmol g-1 CO2 leading to autonomous pressure amplification in a pneumatic demonstrator system up to 428 kPa. According to system level estns. even higher theor. pressure amplification may be achieved between 535 and 1011 kPa.

Adsorption-based phenomena are important in gas sepns., such as the treatment of greenhouse-gas and toxic-gas pollutants, and in water-adsorption-based heat pumps for solar cooling systems. The ability to tune the pore size, shape and functionality of cryst. porous coordination polymers -or metal-org. frameworks (MOFs)-has made them attractive materials for such adsorption-based applications. The flexibility and guest-mol.-dependent response of MOFs give rise to unexpected and often desirable adsorption phenomena. Common to all isothermal gas adsorption phenomena, however, is increased gas uptake with increased pressure. Here we report adsorption transitions in the isotherms of a MOF (DUT-49) that exhibits a neg. gas adsorption; i.e., spontaneous desorption of gas (methane and n-butane) occurs during pressure increase in a defined temp. and pressure range. A combination of in situ powder X-ray diffraction, gas adsorption expts. and simulations shows that this adsorption behavior is controlled by a sudden hysteretic structural deformation and pore contraction of the MOF, which releases guest mols. These findings may enable technologies using frameworks capable of neg. gas adsorption for pressure amplification in micro- and macroscopic system engineering. Neg. gas adsorption extends the series of counterintuitive phenomena such as neg. thermal expansion and neg. refractive indexes and may be interpreted as an adsorptive analog of force-amplifying neg. compressibility transitions proposed for metamaterials.

The surface area is one of the most important quantities for characterizing novel porous materials. The BET anal. is the std. method for detg. surface areas from nitrogen adsorption isotherms and was originally derived for multilayer gas adsorption onto flat surfaces. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a relatively new class of cryst., porous materials that exhibit very large BET surface areas. These materials are microporous and possess surfaces that are far from flat. In some MOFs, adsorption occurs through a pore-filling mechanism rather than by layer formation. Thus, it is unclear whether BET surface area nos. reported for these materials are truly meaningful. Given the std. practice of reporting BET surface areas for novel porous materials, a crit. test of the BET method is much needed. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were used to predict adsorption isotherms for nitrogen in MOFs. The predicted isotherms were used as pseudoexperimental data to test the applicability of the BET theory for obtaining surface areas of microporous MOFs. BET surface areas calcd. from the simulated isotherms agree very well with the accessible surface areas calcd. directly from the crystal structures in a geometric fashion. The surface areas agree well with exptl. reports in the literature. These results provide a strong validation that the BET theory can be used to obtain surface areas of MOFs.

Calcns. based on an accurate (compared to mol. simulations) nonlocal d. functional theory were made to det. adsorption isotherms for simple fluids on single surfaces and in slit-shaped pores for a wide range of pore sizes, fluid-wall adsorption strengths and temps. The calcns. are for smooth structureless walls interacting with the (10,4,3) potential, and the intermol. interactions between fluid mols. are of Lennard-Jones form. The calcns. are used to classify the adsorption behavior into 7 classes. Six of these correspond to the IUPAC classification scheme (K. Sing et al., 1985), and the 7th corresponds to capillary evapn. (drying). The range of conditions that give each of these classes are identified. Qual. comparisons with expt. data are made, and some typical phase diagrams for fluids in such pores are described. All calcns. are based on the single pore model. While a distribution of pore sizes easily can be introduced with this model, interconnection of pores is neglected. Although all 6 of the IUPAC classes are produced with the single pore model, details of the hysteresis loops in classes IV and V are not reproduced.

Crystalline metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are formed by reticular synthesis, which creates strong bonds between inorganic and organic units. Careful selection of MOF constituents can yield crystals of ultrahigh porosity and high thermal and chemical stability. These characteristics allow the interior of MOFs to be chemically altered for use in gas separation, gas storage, and catalysis, among other applications. The precision commonly exercised in their chemical modification and the ability to expand their metrics without changing the underlying topology have not been achieved with other solids. MOFs whose chemical composition and shape of building units can be multiply varied within a particular structure already exist and may lead to materials that offer a synergistic combination of properties.

A new zirconium inorganic building brick forming metal organic frameworks with exceptional stability
Cavka Jasmina Hafizovic; Jakobsen Soren; Olsbye Unni; Guillou Nathalie; Lamberti Carlo; Bordiga Silvia; Lillerud Karl Petter
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Porous crystals are strategic materials with industrial applications within petrochemistry, catalysis, gas storage, and selective separation. Their unique properties are based on the molecular-scale porous character. However, a principal limitation of zeolites and similar oxide-based materials is the relatively small size of the pores, typically in the range of medium-sized molecules, limiting their use in pharmaceutical and fine chemical applications. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) provided a breakthrough in this respect. New MOFs appear at a high and an increasing pace, but the appearances of new, stable inorganic building bricks are rare. Here we present a new zirconium-based inorganic building brick that allows the synthesis of very high surface area MOFs with unprecedented stability. The high stability is based on the combination of strong Zr-O bonds and the ability of the inner Zr6-cluster to rearrange reversibly upon removal or addition of mu3-OH groups, without any changes in the connecting carboxylates. The weak thermal, chemical, and mechanical stability of most MOFs is probably the most important property that limits their use in large scale industrial applications. The Zr-MOFs presented in this work have the toughness needed for industrial applications; decomposition temperature above 500 degrees C and resistance to most chemicals, and they remain crystalline even after exposure to 10 tons/cm2 of external pressure.

A review. Among the large family of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), Zr-based MOFs, which exhibit rich structure types, outstanding stability, intriguing properties and functions, are foreseen as one of the most promising MOF materials for practical applications. Although this specific type of MOF is still in its early stage of development, significant progress was made in recent years. Herein, advances in Zr-MOFs since 2008 are summarized and reviewed from three aspects: design and synthesis, structure, and applications. Four synthesis strategies implemented in building and/or modifying Zr-MOFs as well as their scale-up prepn. under green and industrially feasible conditions are illustrated 1st. Zr-MOFs with various structural types are then classified and discussed in terms of different Zr-based secondary building units and org. ligands. Finally, applications of Zr-MOFs in catalysis, mol. adsorption and sepn., drug delivery, and fluorescence sensing, and as porous carriers are highlighted. Such a review based on a specific type of MOF is expected to provide guidance for the in-depth study of MOFs towards practical applications.

In the past two decades, reticular chem. has developed into a powerful tool for the design and synthesis of porous, cryst. framework materials. The discovery of the first hexanuclear, zirconium cluster-based MOF (i.e. UiO-66; fcu net) led to a vast library of functional Zr-MOFs with various properties. The versatile connectivity of zirconium hexanuclear clusters and the adaptable tunability of org. ligands have resulted in the rational synthesis of a large set of Zr-MOFs based on edge-transitive nets; these nets commonly exists in cryst. network structures as suggested by reticular chem. In this review, we summarize recent advances in the synthesis of zirconium cluster-based MOFs in the light of reticular chem. design principles. Isoreticular tuning of MOF parent structures and post-synthetic modification of Zr-MOFs for targeted applications are also deliberated.

It is a general and common practice to carry out single-crystal x-ray diffraction expts. at cryogenic temps. to obtain high-resoln. data. This practice is not always applicable to metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), esp. when these structures are highly porous. Two new MOFs are reported, MOF-1004 and MOF-1005, for which the collection of the diffraction data at lower temp. (100 K) did not give data of sufficient quality to allow structure soln. Collection of data at higher temp. (290 K) gave at.-resoln. data for MOF-1004 and MOF-1005, allowing for structure soln. This inverse behavior, contrary to normal practice, is also true for some well-established MOFs (MOF-177 and UiO-67). Close examn. of the x-ray diffraction data obtained for all 4 of these MOFs at various temps. Disordered guest-framework interactions play a profound role in introducing disorder at low temp., and the diminishing strength of these interactions at high temps. reduces the disorder and gives high-resoln. diffraction data. The finding here probably is more widely applicable to other highly porous MOFs and crystals contg. highly disordered mols.

Structural characterization via synchrotron single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) revealed the one-dimensional pore architecture of DUT-98, envisioned in silico. After supercrit. solvent extn., distinctive responses towards various gases stimulated reversible structural transformations, as detected using coupled synchrotron diffraction and physisorption techniques. DUT-98 shows a surprisingly low water uptake but a high selectivity for pore opening towards specific gases and vapors (N2, CO2, n-butane, alcs.) at characteristic pressure resulting in multiple steps in the adsorption isotherm and hysteretic behavior upon desorption.

A review. The past 20 years have witnessed tremendous advances in the field of porous materials, including the development of novel metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that show great potential for practical applications aimed at addressing global environmental and industrial challenges. A crit. tool enabling this progress has been reticular chem., through which researchers can design materials that exhibit highly regular (i.e. edge-transitive) topologies, based on the assembly of geometrically-matched building blocks into specific nets. However, innovation sometimes demands that researchers steer away from default topologies to instead pursue unusual geometries. In this perspective, we cover this aspect and introduce the concept of geometry mismatch, in which seemingly incompatible building blocks are combined to generate non-default structures. We describe diverse MOF assemblies built through geometry mismatch generated by use of ligand bend-angles, twisted functional groups, zigzag ligands and other elements, focusing on carboxylate-based MOFs combined with common inorg. clusters. We aim to provide a fresh perspective on rational design of MOFs and to help readers understand the countless options now available to achieve greater structural complexity in MOFs.

The 1st three-dimensional Cr(III) dicarboxylate, MIL-53as or CrIII(OH)·{O2C-C6H4-CO2}·{HO2C-C6H4-CO2H}0.75, was obtained under hydrothermal conditions (as: as-synthesized). The free acid can be removed by calcination giving the resulting solid, MIL-53ht or CrIII(OH)·{O2C-C6H4-CO2}. At room temp., MIL-53ht adsorbs atm. H2O immediately to give CrIII(OH)·{O2C-C6H4-CO2}·H2O or MIL-53lt (lt: low-temp. form, ht:high-temp. form). Structures, which were detd. by using x-ray powder diffraction data, are built up from chains of Cr(III) octahedra linked through terephthalate dianions. This creates a three-dimensional structure with an array of 1-dimensional large pore channels filled with free disordered terephthalic mols. (MIL-53as) or H2O mols. (MIL-53lt); when the free mols. are removed, this leads to a nanoporous solid (MIL-53ht) with a Langmuir surface area over 1500 m2/g. The transition between the hydrated form (MIL-53lt) and the anhyd. solid (MIL-53ht) is fully reversible and followed by a very high breathing effect (more than 5 Å), the pores being clipped in the presence of H2O mols. (MIL-53lt) and reopened when the channels are empty (MIL-53ht). The thermal behavior of the two solids was studied using TGA and x-ray thermodiffractometry. The sorption properties of MIL-53lt also were studied using several org. solvents. Finally, magnetism measurements performed on MIL-53as and MIL-53lt revealed that these two phases are antiferromagnetic with Neel temps. TN of 65 and 55 K, resp. Crystal data for MIL-53as is as follows: orthorhombic space group Pnam with a 17.340(1), b 12.178(1), c 6.822(1) Å, and Z = 4. Crystal data for MIL-53ht is as follows: orthorhombic space group Imcm with a 16.733(1), b 13.038(1), c 6.812(1) Å, and Z = 4. Crystal data for MIL-53lt is as follows: monoclinic space group C2/c with a 19.685(4), b 7.849(1), c 6.782(1) Å, β 104.90(1)°, and Z = 4.

Rod Packings and Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed from Rod-Shaped Secondary Building Units
Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Kim, Jaheon; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Chen, Banglin; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.

The principal structure possibilities for packing infinite rod-shaped building blocks are described. Some basic nets derived from linking simple rods (helixes and ladders) are then enumerated. The authors demonstrate the usefulness of the concept of rod secondary building units in the design and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). Accordingly, the authors present the prepn., characterization, and crystal structures of 14 new MOFs (named MOF-69A-C and MOF-70-80) of 12 different structure types, belonging to rod packing motifs, and show how their structures are related to basic nets. The MOFs reported herein are of polytopic carboxylates and contain one of Zn, Pb, Co, Cd, Mn, or Tb. The inclusion properties of the most open members are presented as evidence that MOF structures with rod building blocks can indeed be designed to have permanent porosity and rigid architectures.

A review. Rod MOFs are metal-org. frameworks in which the metal-contg. secondary building units consist of infinite rods of linked metal-centered polyhedra. For such materials the authors identify the points of extension, often atoms, which define the interface between the org. and inorg. components of the structure. The pattern of points of extension defines a shape such as a helix, ladder, helical ribbon or cylinder tiling. The linkage of these shapes into a 3-dimensional framework in turn defines a net characteristic of the original structure. Some scores of rod MOF structures are illustrated and deconstructed into their underlying nets in this way. Crystallog. data for all nets in their max. symmetry embeddings are provided.

Two new Zr-based metal-org. frameworks [Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)6(BDC)3] (CAU-26) and [Zr5O4(OH)4(OAc)4(BDC)2] (CAU-27) are reported, which were synthesized from HOAc, a rarely used but green and sustainable solvent (BDC2-: 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). Structure detn. aided by automated electron diffraction tomog. revealed that CAU-26 [Zr6O4(OH)4(OAc)6(BDC)3] is composed of layers of known {Zr6O8} clusters interconnected by terephthalate ions. In contrast CAU-27 [Zr5O4(OH)4(OAc)4(BDC)2] exhibits a three-dimensional structure with a so far unknown type of 1-dimensional inorg. building unit (IBU), which can be rationalized as condensed polyhedron-sharing chains of {Zr6O8} clusters. CAU-26 occurs as an intermediate of the CAU-27 synthesis and can be isolated easily, when reaction temp. and time are decreased. The authors were also able to synthesize two isoreticular derivs. of CAU-27 with extended linker mols. by implementing 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC) and 5,5'-dicarboxy-2,2'-bipyridine (H2BIPY). All materials show high thermal and chem. stability as well as permanent microporosity. The excellent stability of CAU-27-BIPY was exploited to synthesize an Ir-supported heterogeneous MOF-based catalyst for the direct C-H borylation of arenes.

Engineering Structural Dynamics of Zirconium Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Natural C4 Linkers
Wang, Sujing; Xhaferaj, Nertil; Wahiduzzaman, Mohammad; Oyekan, Kolade; Li, Xiao; Wei, Kevin; Zheng, Bin; Tissot, Antoine; Marrot, Jerome; Shepard, William; Martineau-Corcos, Charlotte; Filinchuk, Yaroslav; Tan, Kui; Maurin, Guillaume; Serre, Christian

Engineering the structural flexibility of metal-org. framework (MOF) materials for sepn.-related applications remains a great challenge. We present here a strategy of mixing rigid and soft linkers in a MOF structure to achieve tunable structural flexibility, as exemplified in a series of stable isostructural Zr-MOFs built with natural C4 linkers (fumaric acid, succinic acid, and malic acid). As shown by the differences in linker bond stretching and bending freedom, these MOFs display distinct responsive dynamics to external stimuli, namely, changes in temp. or guest mol. type. Comprehensive in situ characterizations reveal a clear correlation between linker character and MOF dynamic behavior, which leads to the discovery of a multivariate flexible MOF. It shows an optimal combination of both good working capacity and significantly enhanced selectivity for CO2/N2 sepn. In principle, it provides a new avenue for potentially improving the ability of microporous MOFs to sep. other gaseous and liq. mixts.

The Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database of, and symbols for, crystal nets
O'Keeffe, Michael; Peskov, Maxim A.; Ramsden, Stuart J.; Yaghi, Omar M.
Accounts of Chemical Research
(
2008
),
41
(
12
),
1782-1789
CODEN:
ACHRE4
; ISSN:
0001-4842
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
During the past decade, interest has grown tremendously in the design and synthesis of cryst. materials constructed from mol. clusters linked by extended groups of atoms. Most notable are metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), in which polyat. inorg. metal-contg. clusters are joined by polytopic linkers. (Although these materials are sometimes referred to as coordination polymers, we prefer to differentiate them, because MOFs are based on strong linkages that yield robust frameworks.) The realization that MOFs could be designed and synthesized in a rational way from mol. building blocks led to the emergence of a discipline that we call reticular chem.MOFs can be represented as a special kind of graph called a periodic net. Such descriptions date back to the earliest crystallog. studies but have become much more common recently because thousands of new structures and hundreds of underlying nets have been reported. In the simplest cases (e.g., the structure of diamond), the atoms in the crystal become the vertices of the net, and bonds are the links (edges) that connect them. In the case of MOFs, polyat. groups act as the vertices and edges of the net.Because of the explosive growth in this area, a need has arisen for a universal system of nomenclature, classification, identification, and retrieval of these topol. structures. We have developed a system of symbols for the identification of three periodic nets of interest, and this system is now in wide use. In this Account, we explain the underlying methodol. of assigning symbols and describe the Reticular Chem. Structure Resource (RCSR), in which about 1600 such nets are collected and illustrated in a database that can be searched by symbol, name, keywords, and attributes. The resource also contains searchable data for polyhedra and layers.The database entries come from systematic enumerations or from known chem. compds. or both. In the latter case, refs. to occurrences are provided. We describe some crystallog., topol., and other attributes of nets and explain how they are reported in the database. We also describe how the database can be used as a tool for the design and structural anal. of new materials. Assocd. with each net is a natural tiling, which is a natural partition of space into space-filling tiles. The database allows export of data that can be used to analyze and illustrate such tilings.

PLATON SQUEEZE: a tool for the calculation of the disordered solvent contribution to the calculated structure factors
Spek, Anthony L.
Acta Crystallographica, Section C: Structural Chemistry
(
2015
),
71
(
1
),
9-18

ACSCGG
; ISSN:
2053-2296
.
(
International Union of Crystallography
)
The completion of a crystal structure detn. is often hampered by the presence of embedded solvent mols. or ions that are seriously disordered. Their contribution to the calcd. structure factors in the least-squares refinement of a crystal structure has to be included in some way. Traditionally, an atomistic solvent disorder model is attempted. Such an approach is generally to be preferred, but it does not always lead to a satisfactory result and may even be impossible in cases where channels in the structure are filled with continuous electron d. This paper documents the SQUEEZE method as an alternative means of addressing the solvent disorder issue. It conveniently interfaces with the 2014 version of the least-squares refinement program SHELXL [Sheldrick (2015). Acta Cryst. C71. In the press] and other refinement programs that accept externally provided fixed contributions to the calcd. structure factors. The PLATON SQUEEZE tool calcs. the solvent contribution to the structure factors by back-Fourier transformation of the electron d. found in the solvent-accessible region of a phase-optimized difference electron-d. map. The actual least-squares structure refinement is delegated to, for example, SHELXL. The current versions of PLATON SQUEEZE and SHELXL now address several of the unnecessary complications with the earlier implementation of the SQUEEZE procedure that were a necessity because least-squares refinement with the now superseded SHELXL97 program did not allow for the input of fixed externally provided contributions to the structure-factor calcn. It is no longer necessary to subtract the solvent contribution temporarily from the obsd. intensities to be able to use SHELXL for the least-squares refinement, since that program now accepts the solvent contribution from an external file ( file) if the ABIN instruction is used. In addn., many twinned structures contg. disordered solvents are now also treatable by SQUEEZE. The details of a SQUEEZE calcn. are now automatically included in the CIF archive file, along with the unmerged reflection data. The current implementation of the SQUEEZE procedure is described, and discussed and illustrated with three examples. Two of them are based on the reflection data of published structures and one on synthetic reflection data generated for a published structure.

Towards general network architecture design criteria for negative gas adsorption transitions in ultraporous frameworks
Krause Simon; Evans Jack D; Bon Volodymyr; Senkovska Irena; Kolbe Felicitas; Ehrling Sebastian; Troschke Erik; Getzschmann Jurgen; Brunner Eike; Kaskel Stefan; Evans Jack D; Coudert Francois-Xavier; Iacomi Paul; Llewellyn Philip L; Tobbens Daniel M; Franz Alexandra; Wallacher Dirk; Yot Pascal G; Maurin Guillaume
Nature communications
(
2019
),
10
(
1
),
3632
ISSN:
.
Switchable metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been proposed for various energy-related storage and separation applications, but the mechanistic understanding of adsorption-induced switching transitions is still at an early stage. Here we report critical design criteria for negative gas adsorption (NGA), a counterintuitive feature of pressure amplifying materials, hitherto uniquely observed in a highly porous framework compound (DUT-49). These criteria are derived by analysing the physical effects of micromechanics, pore size, interpenetration, adsorption enthalpies, and the pore filling mechanism using advanced in situ X-ray and neutron diffraction, NMR spectroscopy, and calorimetric techniques parallelised to adsorption for a series of six isoreticular networks. Aided by computational modelling, we identify DUT-50 as a new pressure amplifying material featuring distinct NGA transitions upon methane and argon adsorption. In situ neutron diffraction analysis of the methane (CD4) adsorption sites at 111 K supported by grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations reveals a sudden population of the largest mesopore to be the critical filling step initiating structural contraction and NGA. In contrast, interpenetration leads to framework stiffening and specific pore volume reduction, both factors effectively suppressing NGA transitions.

Massive Pressure Amplification by Stimulated Contraction of Mesoporous Frameworks**
Bon, Volodymyr; Krause, Simon; Senkovska, Irena; Grimm, Nico; Wallacher, Dirk; Toebbens, Daniel M.; Kaskel, Stefan
Angewandte Chemie, International Edition
(
2021
),
60
(
21
),
11735-11739
CODEN:
ACIEF5
; ISSN:
1433-7851
.
(
Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
)
Herein we demonstrate mesoporous frameworks interacting with carbon dioxide leading to stimulated structural contractions and massive out-of-equil. pressure amplification well beyond ambient pressure. Carbon dioxide, a non-toxic and non-flammable working medium, is promising for the development of pressure-amplifying frameworks for pneumatic technologies and safety systems. The strong interaction of the fluid with the framework even contracts DUT-46, a framework hitherto considered as non-flexible. Synchrotron-based in situ PXRD/adsorption expts. reveal the characteristic contraction pressure for DUT-49 pressure amplification in the range of 350-680 kPa. The stimulated framework contraction expels 1.1 to 2.4 mmol g-1 CO2 leading to autonomous pressure amplification in a pneumatic demonstrator system up to 428 kPa. According to system level estns. even higher theor. pressure amplification may be achieved between 535 and 1011 kPa.

A pressure-amplifying framework material with negative gas adsorption transitions
Krause, Simon; Bon, Volodymyr; Senkovska, Irena; Stoeck, Ulrich; Wallacher, Dirk; Toebbens, Daniel M.; Zander, Stefan; Pillai, Renjith S.; Maurin, Guillaume; Coudert, Francois-Xavier; Kaskel, Stefan
Nature (London, United Kingdom)
(
2016
),
532
(
7599
),
348-352
CODEN:
NATUAS
; ISSN:
0028-0836
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
Adsorption-based phenomena are important in gas sepns., such as the treatment of greenhouse-gas and toxic-gas pollutants, and in water-adsorption-based heat pumps for solar cooling systems. The ability to tune the pore size, shape and functionality of cryst. porous coordination polymers -or metal-org. frameworks (MOFs)-has made them attractive materials for such adsorption-based applications. The flexibility and guest-mol.-dependent response of MOFs give rise to unexpected and often desirable adsorption phenomena. Common to all isothermal gas adsorption phenomena, however, is increased gas uptake with increased pressure. Here we report adsorption transitions in the isotherms of a MOF (DUT-49) that exhibits a neg. gas adsorption; i.e., spontaneous desorption of gas (methane and n-butane) occurs during pressure increase in a defined temp. and pressure range. A combination of in situ powder X-ray diffraction, gas adsorption expts. and simulations shows that this adsorption behavior is controlled by a sudden hysteretic structural deformation and pore contraction of the MOF, which releases guest mols. These findings may enable technologies using frameworks capable of neg. gas adsorption for pressure amplification in micro- and macroscopic system engineering. Neg. gas adsorption extends the series of counterintuitive phenomena such as neg. thermal expansion and neg. refractive indexes and may be interpreted as an adsorptive analog of force-amplifying neg. compressibility transitions proposed for metamaterials.

Applicability of the BET Method for Determining Surface Areas of Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
Walton, Krista S.; Snurr, Randall Q.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2007
),
129
(
27
),
8552-8556
CODEN:
JACSAT
; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The surface area is one of the most important quantities for characterizing novel porous materials. The BET anal. is the std. method for detg. surface areas from nitrogen adsorption isotherms and was originally derived for multilayer gas adsorption onto flat surfaces. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a relatively new class of cryst., porous materials that exhibit very large BET surface areas. These materials are microporous and possess surfaces that are far from flat. In some MOFs, adsorption occurs through a pore-filling mechanism rather than by layer formation. Thus, it is unclear whether BET surface area nos. reported for these materials are truly meaningful. Given the std. practice of reporting BET surface areas for novel porous materials, a crit. test of the BET method is much needed. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were used to predict adsorption isotherms for nitrogen in MOFs. The predicted isotherms were used as pseudoexperimental data to test the applicability of the BET theory for obtaining surface areas of microporous MOFs. BET surface areas calcd. from the simulated isotherms agree very well with the accessible surface areas calcd. directly from the crystal structures in a geometric fashion. The surface areas agree well with exptl. reports in the literature. These results provide a strong validation that the BET theory can be used to obtain surface areas of MOFs.

Classification of adsorption behavior: simple fluids in pores of slit-shaped geometry
Balbuena, Perla B.; Gubbins, Keith E.
Fluid Phase Equilibria
(
1992
),
76
(
),
21-35
CODEN:
FPEQDT
; ISSN:
0378-3812
.
Calcns. based on an accurate (compared to mol. simulations) nonlocal d. functional theory were made to det. adsorption isotherms for simple fluids on single surfaces and in slit-shaped pores for a wide range of pore sizes, fluid-wall adsorption strengths and temps. The calcns. are for smooth structureless walls interacting with the (10,4,3) potential, and the intermol. interactions between fluid mols. are of Lennard-Jones form. The calcns. are used to classify the adsorption behavior into 7 classes. Six of these correspond to the IUPAC classification scheme (K. Sing et al., 1985), and the 7th corresponds to capillary evapn. (drying). The range of conditions that give each of these classes are identified. Qual. comparisons with expt. data are made, and some typical phase diagrams for fluids in such pores are described. All calcns. are based on the single pore model. While a distribution of pore sizes easily can be introduced with this model, interconnection of pores is neglected. Although all 6 of the IUPAC classes are produced with the single pore model, details of the hysteresis loops in classes IV and V are not reproduced.
